title: 103_hr1240
content: The Act titled "Social Security Domestic Employment Tax Act of 1993" increases the threshold level for cash remuneration for domestic services subject to Social Security employment taxes. The Social Security Act is amended to increase the threshold amount for cash remuneration paid by an employer to an employee for domestic service in a private home. The threshold amount for 1993 is set at $2,000, with the Secretary determining and publishing the threshold amount for each succeeding calendar year. The Social Security Act is amended to increase the threshold amount for cash remuneration paid by an employer to an employee for domestic service in a private home. The threshold amount is determined based on the deemed average total wages for the previous year, with specific rounding rules applied. The term 'domestic service in a private home of the employer' excludes certain types of services. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude cash remuneration paid by an employer to an employee for domestic service in a private home if it is below a certain threshold amount determined under the Social Security Act. This excludes specific types of services from the definition of 'domestic service in a private home of the employer'. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude cash remuneration paid by an employer to an employee for domestic service in a private home if it is below a certain threshold amount determined under the Social Security Act. The amendments made by this section apply to remuneration paid in calendar years after 1992. SEC. 3. Coordination of collection of domestic service employment taxes with income taxes is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 states that returns for domestic service employment taxes are filed on a calendar year basis, with no deposit requirements. Domestic service employment taxes are subject to estimated tax provisions for the employer's taxable year. For the taxable year of the employer starting in a calendar year, adjustments are made in the application of tax under section 6654(d)(2). A transitional rule applies for 1993, increasing the amount under section 6654(d)(1)(B) by 90% of the tax treated under paragraph (1). Domestic service employment taxes refer to taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home under chapters 21 or 23 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The section discusses remuneration for domestic service in a private home of the employer and exceptions where the employer is liable for other employment taxes. The Secretary is authorized to enter into agreements with states to collect state unemployment taxes. The Secretary can enter agreements with states to collect state unemployment taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home. The collected taxes will be treated as domestic service employment taxes and transferred to the state's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. The amount collected will be considered a tax imposed by chapter 23 for subtitle F purposes. The meaning of 'State' is defined in section 3306(j)(1). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 25. The amendments made by this section apply to remuneration paid in calendar years after 1992.
